column1: Truro (; Cornish: Truru) is a cathedral city and civil parish in Cornwall
column2: England
column3: UK. It is Cornwall's county town and only city
column4: as well as being its centre for administration
column5: leisure and retail. Its population was recorded as 18
column6: 766 in the 2011 census. People from Truro are known as Truronians. Truro grew as a centre of trade from its port and then as a stannary town for the tin-mining industry. It became entitled to be called a city in 1876
column7: with the founding of the Diocese of Truro
column8: and thereby became mainland Britain's southernmost city. Places of interest include the Royal Cornwall Museum
column9: Truro Cathedral (completed in 1910)

column1: The origin of Truro's name is debated. It has been said to derive from the Cornish tri-veru meaning "three rivers"
column2: but authorities such as the Oxford Dictionary of English Place Names reject this theory. There are doubts about the "tru" part meaning "three". An expert on Cornish place-names
column3: Oliver Padel
column4: in A Popular Dictionary of Cornish Place-names
column5: called the "three rivers" meaning "possible". Alternatively the name may derive from tre-uro or similar
column6: i. e. the settlement on the river Uro.

column1: The earliest records and archaeological finds of a permanent settlement in the Truro area date from Norman times. A castle was built there in the 12th century by Richard de Luci
column2: Chief Justice of England in the reign of Henry II
column3: who for his services to the court was granted land in Cornwall
column4: including the area surrounding the confluence of the two rivers. The town grew in the shadow of the castle and was awarded borough status to further economic activity. The castle has long since disappeared.

column1: Richard de Lucy fought in Cornwall under Count Alan of Brittany after leaving Falaise late in 1138. The small adulterine castle at Truro
column2: Cornwall (originally the parish of Kenwyn)
column3: later known as "Castellum de Guelon" was probably built by him in 1139–1140. He styled himself "Richard de Lucy
column4: de Trivereu". The castle later passed to Reginald FitzRoy (also known as Reginald de Dunstanville)
column5: an illegitimate son of Henry I
column6: when he was invested by King Stephen as the first Earl of Cornwall. Reginald married Mabel FitzRichard
column7: daughter of William FitzRichard
column8: a substantial landholder in Cornwall. The 75-foot (23 m)-diameter castle was in ruins by 1270 and the motte was levelled in 1840. Today Truro Crown Court stands on the site. In a charter of about 1170
column9: Reginald FitzRoy confirmed to the burgesses of Truro the privileges granted by Richard de Lucy. Richard held ten knights' fees in Cornwall prior to 1135 and at his death the county still accounted for a third of his considerable total holding.By the start of the 14th century Truro was an important port
column10: due to its inland location away from invaders
column12: and a new role as one of Cornwall's stannary towns for assaying and stamping tin and copper from Cornish mines. The Black Death brought a trade recession and an exodus of the population that left the town in a very neglected state. Trade gradually returned and the town regained prosperity in the Tudor period. Local government was awarded in 1589 by a new charter granted by Elizabeth I
column13: giving Truro an elected mayor and control over the port of Falmouth.

column1: During the Civil War in the 17th century
column2: Truro raised a sizeable force to fight for the king and a royalist mint was set up. Defeat by the Parliamentary troops came after the Battle of Naseby in 1646
column3: when the victorious Parliamentarian general Fairfax led his army south-west to relieve Taunton and capture the Royalist-held West Country. The Royalist forces surrendered at Truro while leading Royalist commanders
column4: including Lord Hopton
column5: the Prince of Wales
column6: Sir Edward Hyde
column7: and Lord Capell
column8: fled to Jersey from Falmouth. The mint was moved to Exeter.

column2: Falmouth was awarded its own charter
column3: giving it rights to its harbour and starting a long rivalry between the two towns. The dispute was settled in 1709 with control of the River Fal divided between them. The arms of the city of Truro are "Gules the base wavy of six Argent and Azure
column4: thereon an ancient ship of three masts under sail
column5: on each topmast a banner of St George
column6: on the waves in base two fishes of the second."

column1: Truro prospered in the 18th and 19th centuries. Industry flourished through improved mining methods and higher prices for tin
column2: and the town attracted wealthy mine owners. Elegant Georgian and Victorian townhouses were built
column3: such as those seen today in Lemon Street
column4: named after the mining magnate and local MP Sir William Lemon. Truro became the centre for society in the county
column5: even dubbed "the London of Cornwall".

column1: Throughout those prosperous times Truro remained a social centre
column2: and many notable people came from there. Among the noteworthy were Richard Lander
column3: an explorer who was the first European to reach the mouth of the River Niger in Africa and was awarded the first gold medal of the Royal Geographical Society
column4: and Henry Martyn
column5: who read mathematics at Cambridge
column6: was ordained and became a missionary
column7: translating the New Testament into Urdu and Persian. Others include Humphry Davy
column8: educated in Truro and the inventor of the miner's safety lamp
column9: and Samuel Foote
column10: an actor and playwright from Boscawen Street.

column1: Truro's importance increased later in the 19th century
column2: with an iron-smelting works
column3: potteries
column4: and tanneries. From the 1860s
column5: the Great Western Railway provided a direct link to London Paddington. The Bishopric of Truro Act 1876 gave the town a bishop and later a cathedral. The next year it was granted city status. The New Bridge Street drill hall was completed in the late 19th century.Mining declined in the early 20th century
column6: but Truro remained prosperous as a developing administrative and commercial centre of Cornwall. Today it remains the county retail centre
column7: but like other places
column8: faces concerns over replacement of speciality shops by national chain stores
column9: erosion of identity
column10: and doubts about how to accommodate growth expected in the 21st century.

column1: Truro lies in the centre of western Cornwall
column2: about 9 miles (14 kilometres) from the south coast
column3: at the confluence of the rivers Kenwyn and Allen
column4: which combine as the Truro River – one of a series of creeks
column5: rivers and drowned valleys leading into the River Fal and then to the large natural harbour of Carrick Roads. The valleys form a steep-sided bowl surrounding the city on the north
column6: east and west
column7: open to the Truro River in the south. The bowl shape
column8: along with high precipitation that swells the rivers and a spring tide in the River Fal
column9: were major factors in the 1988 floods that seriously damaged the city centre. Since then
column11: including an emergency dam at New Mill on the River Kenwyn and a tidal barrier on the Truro River.

column1: The city is surrounded by several protected natural areas such as the historic parklands at Pencalenick
column2: and larger areas of ornamental landscape
column3: such as Trelissick Garden and Tregothnan further down the Truro River. An area south-east of the city
column4: around and including Calenick Creek
column5: has been designated an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. Other protected areas include an Area of Great Landscape Value comprising agricultural land and wooded valleys to the north east
column6: and Daubuz Moors
column7: a local nature reserve alongside the River Allen close to the city centre.

column1: Truro has mainly grown and developed around the historic city centre in a nuclear fashion along the slopes of the bowl valley
column2: except for fast linear development along the A390 to the west
column3: towards Threemilestone. As Truro has grown
column4: it has encompassed other settlements as suburbs or districts
column5: including Kenwyn and Moresk to the north
column6: Trelander to the east
column7: Newham to the south
column8: and Highertown
column9: Treliske and Gloweth to the west.

column1: The Truro area has an oceanic climate similar to the rest of Cornwall's. This means even fewer extremes in temperature than in the remainder of England
column2: marked by high rainfall
column3: cool summers and mild winters with infrequent frosts.

column2: which includes parts of surrounding parishes
column3: had a 2001 census population of 20
column4: 920. By 2011 the population
column5: including Threemilestone
column6: was 23
column7: 040. Its status as the county's prime destination for retail and leisure and administration is unusual in that it is only its fourth most populous settlement. Furthermore
column8: population growth at 10.5 per cent between 1971 and 1998 was slow compared with other Cornish towns and Cornwall as a whole.Major employers include the Royal Cornwall Hospital
column9: Cornwall Council
column10: and Truro College. There are about 22
column13: 500 economically active people living in the city. Commutes into Truro are a major factor in its traffic congestion. Average earnings are higher than in the rest of Cornwall.

column1: Housing prices in Truro in the 2000s were 8 or more per cent higher than in the rest of Cornwall. Truro was named in 2006 as the top small city in the United Kingdom for rising house prices
column2: at 262 per cent since 1996. There is heavy demand for new housing and a call for inner-city properties to be converted into flats or houses to encourage city-centre living and reduce dependence on cars.

column1: Truro's dominant feature is the Gothic-revival Truro Cathedral
column2: designed by architect John Loughborough Pearson
column3: rising 249 ft (76 m) above the city at its highest spire. It took from 1880 to 1910 to build
column4: on the site of the old St Mary's Church
column5: consecrated over 600 years earlier. Enthusiasts of Georgian architecture are well catered for in the city
column6: with terraces and townhouses along Walsingham Place and Lemon Street often said to be "the finest examples of Georgian architecture west of the city of Bath".The main attraction for regional residents is a wide variety of shops. Truro has various chain stores
column7: speciality shops and markets that reflect its history as a market town. The indoor Pannier Market is open all year with many stalls and small businesses. The city is also popular for catering and for night life
column8: with many bars
column9: clubs and restaurants. Truro houses the Hall for Cornwall
column10: a performing arts and entertainment venue.

column1: The Royal Cornwall Museum is the oldest and premier museum in Cornwall detailing Cornish history and culture. Its collections cover fields such as archaeology
column2: art and geology. Among the exhibits is the so-called Arthur's inscribed stone. Its parks and open spaces include Victoria Gardens
column3: Boscawen Park and Daubuz Moors.

column1: Lemon Quay is the year-round centre of most festivities in Truro.

column2: Truro prepares to partake in the Britain in Bloom competition
column3: with floral displays and hanging baskets dotted around the city throughout the summer. A "continental market" comes to Truro in the holiday-making season
column4: featuring food and craft stalls from France
column5: Spain
column6: Italy
column7: Germany
column8: Belgium
column9: the Netherlands

column2: a Pride event that celebrates diversity and the LGBT community
column3: takes place on the last Saturday of August. The Truro City Carnival
column4: held every September over a weekend
column5: includes various arts and music performances
column6: children's activities
column7: a fireworks display
column8: food and drinks fairs
column9: a circus
column10: and a parade. A half-marathon organised by Truro Running Club also occurs in September
column11: running from the city centre into the country towards Kea
column12: returning to finish at Lemon Quay.

column1: Truro marks Christmas with a Winter Festival that includes a "City of Lights" paper lantern parade. Local schools
column2: colleges
column3: and community and youth groups join in. Students at the local college in Truro create large lanterns
column4: complementing the work of the core artists team. There are Christmas lights throughout the city centre
column5: with a switch-on event
column6: speciality products and craft fairs
column7: late-night shopping evenings
column8: various cathedral events and a firework display on New Year's Eve. Christmas trees are placed on the Piazza and outside the cathedral at High Cross.

column1: Truro temporarily became home to the Cornish Pirates rugby union club for the 2005–2006 season
column2: but the team moved again for the 2006–2007 season to share the ground of Camborne RFC. In April 2018
column3: the construction of a Stadium for Cornwall was under discussion with Cornwall Council
column4: which had pledged £3 million in funding for the £14.3 million project. It is planned for a site in Threemilestone. The town has an amateur rugby union side
column5: Truro RFC
column6: founded in 1885. It belongs to Tribute Western Counties West and plays home games at St Clements Hill. It has hosted the CRFU Cornwall Cup several times.

column2: a football team in the National League South
column3: is the only Cornish club ever to reach this tier of the football pyramid. The club achieved national recognition by winning the FA Vase in 2007
column4: beating A.F.C. Totton 3–1 in only the second ever final at the new Wembley Stadium
column5: and becoming the first Cornish side ever to win that award. Its home ground is Treyew Road. Cornwall County Cricket Club plays some of its home fixtures at Boscawen Park
column6: which is also the home ground of Truro Cricket Club. Truro Fencing Club is one of Britain's flagships
column7: having won numerous national championships
column8: and had three fencers selected for Team GB at the London 2012 Olympics. Other sports amenities include a leisure centre
column9: golf course and tennis courts.

column1: Truro is the centre of Cornwall's local media. The countywide weeklies
column2: the Cornish Guardian and The West Briton
column3: are based in the city
column4: the latter serving the Truro area with its Truro and Mid-Cornwall edition. The city also houses the broadcasting studios of BBC Radio Cornwall
column5: and those of the West district of ITV Westcountry
column6: whose main studio is now in Bristol after a merger with ITV West. This closed the studio in Plymouth and the Westcountry Live programme was replaced by The West Country Tonight.

column1: A mummers play text attributed until recently to Mylor
column2: Cornwall (much quoted in early studies of folk plays
column3: such as The Mummers Play by R. J. E. Tiddy – published posthumously in 1923 – and The English Folk-Play (1933) by E. K. Chambers)
column4: has now been shown
column5: by genealogical and other research
column6: to have originated in Truro around 1780.The widespread tradition of Nine Lessons and Carols originated in Truro in 1880
column7: when its bishop at the time
column8: Edward White Benson
column9: formalised the evening singing of carols before Christmas Day.

column2: a city/parish council
column3: is based upstairs at the Municipal Buildings in Boscawen Street. It runs parks
column4: gardens and planting
column5: mayoral and civic events
column6: support of its overseas twinning
column7: and tourist information. It also considers planning issues and is involved in creating the Truro and Kenwyn Neighbourhood Plan in association with Cornwall Council. The city divides into four wards: Boscawen
column8: Moresk
column9: Tregolls and Trehaverne
column10: with 24 councillors elected for four-year terms.Cornwall Council (a unitary authority) has its base at Lys Kernow (formerly County Hall) west of the city centre. It administers planning

column1: The elected City Council forms Truro's lowest level of government
column2: as one of 213 parish bodies in the county. The governance layer above is the unitary Cornwall Council
column3: directly under central government. It covers Truro's public library
column4: parks and gardens
column5: tourist information centre
column6: allotments and cemeteries. It is affiliated to Truro Chamber of Commerce and other civic bodies.Truro's borough court was first granted in 1153; it became a free borough in 1589
column7: then a city in 1877
column8: receiving letters patent after the Anglican diocese was located there in 1876. However
column9: it forms the eighth smallest in the UK in terms of population
column10: city council area and urban area.

column1: Several towns outside Britain have taken Truro as their name:
Truro is 6 miles (9.7 km) from the A30 trunk road
column2: to which it is linked by the A39 from Falmouth and Penryn. Also passing through is the A390 between Redruth to the west and Liskeard to the east
column3: where it joins the A38 for Plymouth
column4: Exeter and the M5 motorway. Truro as the most southerly city in the United Kingdom is just under 232 miles (373 km) west-south-west of Charing Cross
column5: London.

column1: The city and its surroundings have extensive bus services
column2: mostly operated by First Kernow and Transport for Cornwall. Most terminate at Truro bus station near Lemon Quay. A permanent Park and Ride scheme
column3: known as Park for Truro
column4: which began operation in August 2008. Buses based at Langarth Park in Threemilestone carry commuters into the city via Truro College
column5: the Royal Cornwall Hospital Treliske
column6: County Hall
column7: Truro railway station
column8: the Royal Cornwall Museum and Victoria Square
column9: and through to a second car park on the east side of Truro. Truro also has Longer-distance bus services run by National Express.

column2: about 1 km (0.6 mi) from the city centre
column3: is on the Cornish Main Line with direct connections to London Paddington and to the Midlands
column4: North and Scotland. North-east of the station is a 28-metre-high (92-foot) stone viaduct with views over the city
column5: cathedral
column6: and Truro River in the distance. The viaduct – the longest on the line – replaced Isambard Kingdom Brunel's wooden Carvedras Viaduct in 1904. Connecting to the main line at Truro station is the Maritime Line to Falmouth in the south.

column1: Truro's first railway station was at Highertown. It was opened in 1852 by the West Cornwall Railway for trains to Redruth and Penzance
column2: and was known as Truro Road Station. It was extended to the Truro River at Newham in 1855
column3: but closed
column4: so that Newham served as the terminus. When the Cornwall Railway connected the line to Plymouth
column5: their trains ran to the present station above the city centre. The West Cornwall Railway (WCR) diverted most of its passenger trains to the new station
column6: leaving Newham mainly as a goods station until it closed in 1971. The WCR became part of the Great Western Railway. The route from Highertown to Newham is now a cycle path
column7: which takes a countryside loop through the south side of the city. The steam locomotive
column8: the City of Truro
column9: was built in 1903 and still runs on UK mainline and preserved railways.

column2: Cornwall's main airport
column3: is 12 mi (19 km) north of Truro. It was thought in 2017 to be the "fastest growing airport" in the UK. It has regular flights to London Heathrow and other airports
column4: and to the Isles of Scilly
column5: Dublin and Düsseldorf
column6: Germany.There is also a boat link to Falmouth along the Truro and Fal four times daily
column7: tide permitting. The fleet run by Enterprise Boats as part of the Fal River Links calls on the way at Malpas
column8: Trelissick
column9: Tolverne and St Mawes.

column1: The old parish church of Truro was St Mary's
column2: which was incorporated into the cathedral in the later 19th century. The building dates from 1518
column3: with a later tower and spire
column4: dating from 1769. Parts of the town were in the parishes of Kenwyn and St Clement (Moresk) until the mid 19th century
column5: when other parishes were created. St George's church in Truro
column6: designed by the Reverend William Haslam
column7: vicar of Baldhu
column8: was built of Cornish granite in 1855; it is lofty and imposing. The parish of St George's Truro formed from part of Kenwyn in 1846. In 1865 two more parishes were created: St John's from part of Kenwyn and St Paul's from part of St Clement. St George's contains a large wall painting behind the high altar which was the work of Stephany Cooper in the 1920s. Her father Canon Cooper had been a missionary in Zanzibar and elsewhere. The theme of the mural painting is "Three Heavens": the first heaven has views of Zanzibar and its cathedral (a happy period in the life of the artist); the second heaven has views of the city of Truro including the cathedral
column9: the railway viaduct and St George's church (another happy period in the life of the artist); the third heaven is above the others which are separated from it by the River of Life (Christ is represented bridging the river and 17 saints including St Piran and St Kenwyn are depicted in this part).Charles William Hempel was organist of St. Mary's Church for forty years from 1804
column10: supplementing his income by teaching music. In 1805 he composed and printed Psalms from the New Version for the use of the Congregation of St. Mary's
column11: and in 1812 Sacred Melodies for the same congregation. These melodies became very popular.

column1: The oldest church in Truro is at Kenwyn
column2: on the northern side of the city. It dates from the 14th and 15th centuries
column3: but it was almost entirely rebuilt in 1820
column4: having deteriorated to the point where it had been deemed unsafe and had to be shut.St John's Church (dedicated to St John the Evangelist) was built in 1828 (architect P. Sambell) in the Classical style on a rectangular plan and with a gallery. Alterations were carried out in the 1890s.

column1: St Paul's Church was built in 1848. The chancel was replaced in 1882–1884
column2: the new chancel being the work of J. D. Sedding. The tower is "broad and strong" (Pevsner) and the exterior of the aisles are ornamented in Sedding's version of the Perpendicular style. In the parish of St Paul is the former Convent of the Epiphany (Anglican) at Alverton House
column3: Tregolls Road
column4: an early 19th-century house. The house was extended for the convent of the Community of the Epiphany and the chapel was built in 1910 by Edmund H. Sedding. The sisterhood was founded by the Bishop of Truro
column5: George Howard Wilkinson
column6: in 1883 and closed in 2001 when two surviving nuns moved into care homes. The sisters had been involved in pastoral and educational work and care of the cathedral and St Paul's Church. St Paul's Church
column7: built with a tower on a river bed with poor foundations
column8: has fallen into disrepair and is no longer in use. Services are now held at the churches of St Clement
column9: St George
column10: and St John. St Paul and St Clement form a united benefice
column11: as do St George and St John.

column3: which has a broad granite front (1830

column6: e. g. St Piran's Roman Catholic church and All Saints

column8: and some in schools or halls. St Piran's
column9: dedicated to Our Lady of the Portal and St Piran

column11: for which she received the Benemerenti Medal from the Pope. The Baptist church building occupies the site of the former Lake's pottery
column12: one of the oldest in Cornwall.

column1: A free grammar school associated with St Mary's Church was endowed in the 16th century. Its distinguished pupils include: the scientist Sir Humphrey Davy; the general Sir Hussey Vivian; and the clergyman
column2: Henry Martyn. The former Truro Girls Grammar School was converted into a Sainsbury's supermarket.Educational institutions in Truro today include:

Truro has many proposed development schemes and plans
column2: the majority of which are intended to counter the main problems it faces
column3: notably traffic congestion and lack of housing.

column1: Major proposals include the construction of a distributor road to carry traffic away from the busy Threemilestone-Treliske-Highertown corridor
column2: reconnecting at either Green Lane or Morlaix Avenue. This will also serve the new housing planned for that area.Changes are proposed for the city centre
column3: such as pedestrianisation of the main shopping streets and beautification of a list of uncharacteristic storefronts built in the 1960s. New retail developments on the current Carrick District Council site and Garras Wharf waterfront site will provide more space for shops
column4: open spaces and public amenities. Along with the redevelopment of the waterfront
column5: a tidal barrier is planned to dam water into the Truro River
column6: which is currently blighted by mud banks that appear at low tide.Controversial plans include the construction of a new stadium for Truro City F.C. and the Cornish Pirates
column7: and relocation of the city's golf course to make way for more housing. A smaller project is the addition of two large sculptures in the Piazza.
